'''Pichilemu''' ({{Lang-arn|Small forest}}, {{IPA-es|pitʃiˈlemu|pron|Es-Pichilemu-2.ogg}}), originally known as '''Pichilemo''',<ref name="DGRC">{{Cite DGRC|wstitle=Pichilemo (Puerto de)}}</ref> is a beach resort [[cities in Chile|city]] and [[communes of Chile|commune]] in central [[Chile]], and capital of [[Cardenal Caro Province]]. The commune comprises an urban centre and twenty-two villages, such as [[Ciruelos]], [[Cáhuil]], and [[Espinillo, Chile|Espinillo]]. It is located southwest of [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]], the capital of Chile. Pichilemu had over 13,000 residents as of 2012.
The Pichilemu area was long populated by the indigenous [[Promaucaes]]. European-Chilean development began in the mid-sixteenth century, as ''[[conquistador]]'' [[Pedro de Valdivia]] gave Juan Gómez de Almagro the Topocalma encomienda (which included the current territory of Pichilemu) in January 1541. Pichilemu was established as an "autonomous commune" on 22 December 1891, by decree of the President [[Jorge Montt]] and Interior Minister Manuel José Irarrázabal. [[Agustín Ross Edwards]], a Chilean politician and member of the [[Edwards family|Ross Edwards family]], planned to develop it as a beach resort on the Pacific Ocean for upper-class [[Chilean people|Chileans]].
Pichilemu is home to five of the [[National Monuments of Chile]]: [[Agustín Ross Cultural Centre]] and [[Agustín Ross Park|Park]]; the wooden railway station, [[#Estación Pichilemu|Estación Pichilemu]]; El Árbol tunnel; and the Caballo de Agua. Part of the city was declared a ''Zona Típica'' ("Traditional Area" or "Heritage Site") by the [[National Monuments Council]], in 2004.
The city is part of District No. 35 and is in the ninth senatorial constituency of [[O'Higgins Region]] [[Electoral divisions of Chile|electoral division]]. Pichilemu is home to the main beach in [[O'Higgins Region]]. It is a tourist destination for [[surfing]], [[windsurf]]ing and [[funboard]]ing.
Tourism is the main industry of the city, but forestry and handicrafts are also important. Pichilemu has many expansive dark sand beaches. Several surf championships take place in the city each year at [[Punta de Lobos]], which according to [[Fodor's]] is "widely considered the best surfing in South America all year-round."
== History == {{Main|History of Pichilemu}} Pichilemu was inhabited by [[Promaucaes]], a pre-Columbian tribal group, until the [[Conquest of Chile|Spanish conquest of Chile]].<ref name="Capital Surf">{{Cite web |author=del Río Pereira – Blanca, Carmen |title=Historia regional desde la llegada del español hasta el siglo XIX : Los pueblos precolombinos |trans_title=Regional History from the Arrival of the Spanish until the 19th Century: The Pre-Columbian peoples |publisher=Pro-O'Higgins Tagle Arduengo |language=Spanish |url= http://www.pro-ohiggins.cl/libro/cuerpo/2_2_1.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707012002/http://www.pro-ohiggins.cl/libro/cuerpo/2_2_1.html|archivedate=7 July 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref> They were [[hunter-gatherer]]s and [[fisherman|fishermen]] who lived primarily along the [[Cachapoal River|Cachapoal]] and [[Maule River|Maule]] rivers.<ref name="Capital Surf" /> The remaining Promaucaes were assimilated into Chilean society through a process of [[hispanicisation]] and [[mestizo|mestisation]] after the [[conquest of Chile]].<ref name="Conflicto y armonías">{{Cite book |author=Sarmiento, Domingo Faustino |year=1915 |title=Conflicto y armonías de las razas en América |trans_title=Conflict and harmony of the races in America |language=es |publisher=Buenos Aires : "La Cultura Argentina" |url=https://archive.org/details/conflictoyarmo00sarm |accessdate=11 September 2010 }}</ref>
[[Aureliano Oyarzún]], professor of [[anatomical pathology|pathology]] at [[University of Chile]], investigated pre-Ceramic [[midden]]s from Pichilemu and [[Cahuil]]. His book ''Crónicas de Pichilemu–Cáhuil'' (''Chronicles of Pichilemu–Cáhuil'') was published posthumously, in 1957.<ref name="Crónicas de Pichilemu-Cahuil">{{cite book |author=Oyarzún, Aureliano |title=Crónicas de Pichilemu–Cahuil |trans_title=Chronicles of Pichilemu–Cáhuil|publisher=Imprenta Universitaria, Publicaciones del Museo de Etnología y Antropología de Chile, Nº 4 and 5, Year I |year=1957 |language=Spanish}}</ref> [[Tomás Guevara]] published two volumes of ''Historia de Chile, Chile Prehispánico'' (''History of Chile, Pre-Hispanic Chile'') in 1929, which discusses the [[indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous]] centre of [[Apalta]], the Pichilemu middens, the [[Malloa, Chile|Malloa]] [[petroglyphs]], a stone cup from [[Nancagua]], and pottery finds in [[Peralillo]].<ref name="Región de O'Higgins"/>
[[José Toribio Medina]] (1852–1930), who was a writer and [[historiographer]], spent most of his life in [[Colchagua Province]], and completed his first archeological investigations in Pichilemu. In 1908, he published ''[[Los Restos Indígenas de Pichilemu]]'' ({{lang-en|The Indigenous Remains of Pichilemu}}),<ref name="Restos indígenas">{{Cite book |author=Medina, José Toribio |authorlink=José Toribio Medina |year=1908 |title=Los restos indígenas de Pichilemu |trans_title=The indigenous remains of Pichilemu |language=Spanish |publisher=Imprenta Cervantes |url= https://archive.org/details/losrestosindgen00medigoog |accessdate=20 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="Región de O'Higgins">{{cite book |title=Región de O'Higgins: Breve relación del patrimonio natural y cultural |trans_title=O'Higgins Region: Brief relationship of the natural and cultural heritage |author=Carmen del Río Pereira Blanca Tagle Arduengo |publisher=Pro-O'Higgins |year=2009 |language=Spanish}}</ref> in which he stated that the Indians that were inhabiting Pichilemu when the Spaniards arrived at Chile were Promaucaes, part of the Topocalma encomienda, given on 24 January 1544, by [[Pedro de Valdivia]] to Juan Gómez de Almagro, therefore establishing Pichilemu.<ref name="Restos indígenas"/>
During the [[Colonial Chile|colonial]] and [[Republican Chile|Republican]] periods, [[agriculture]] was promoted by the government. Many Chilean [[hacienda]]s (estates) were successful during this time, including the Pichileminian [[Hacienda San Antonio de Petrel]].<ref name="Región de O'Higgins"/> Part of the land where San Antonio de Petrel was created was given by the [[Captaincy General of Chile]] to Bartolomé de Rojas y Puebla in 1611, who later acquired more lands in order to establish it.<ref name="económicas">{{Cite web|url= http://www.pro-ohiggins.cl/libro/cuerpo/2_2_3.html|author=Carmen del Río Pereira Blanca Tagle Arduengo |year=2009 |language=es|title=Historia regional desde la llegada del español hasta el siglo XIX: Actividades económicas|publisher=Pro-O'Higgins |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306182539/http://www.pro-ohiggins.cl/libro/cuerpo/2_2_3.html |archivedate=6 March 2012|deadurl=yes}}</ref> San Antonio de Petrel produced [[leather]], [[jerky (food)|jerky]], [[sole (shoe)|soles]], [[tallow]], and [[shell cordovan|cordovan]], as well as other products which would later be exported to Peru, or sold in [[Santiago]] and [[Valparaíso]].<ref name="económicas"/> San Antonio de Petrel was bordered by properties of Lauriano Gaete and Ninfa Vargas, and Pedro Pavez Polanco.
The area around Pichilemu was very densely populated, especially in [[Cáhuil]], where there are salt deposits that were exploited by natives. Pichilemu has had censuses taken since the 17th century.<ref name="Thesis Municipality"/>
[[File:Avenida Ortúzar, 1925.jpg|thumb|left|[[Daniel Ortúzar]] Avenue, in 1925.]]
In 1872, [[President of Chile]] [[Aníbal Pinto]] commissioned the [[corvette]] captain [[Francisco Vidal Gormaz]] to perform a survey of the coast between Tumán Creek and Boca del Mataquito. He concluded that Pichilemu was the best place to construct a ferry. The family of [[Daniel Ortúzar]], inheritors of the hacienda San Antonio de Petrel, constructed a dock in 1875, which served as a fishing port for a few years, and would be decreed as a "minor dock" by President [[José Manuel Balmaceda]] in 1887.<ref name="Thesis Municipality"/><ref name="En nuestra tierra huasa">{{cite book |author=León Vargas, Victor |title=En Nuestra Tierra Huasa de Colchagua. Energía y Motores. |trans_title=In Our Huasa Land of Colchagua: Energy and Motors. |publisher=Ed. Museo de Colchagua – Impresos Universitaria, S.A. |place=[[Santiago de Chile]] |year=1996 |language=es}}</ref><ref name="Puerto">{{cite web|title=Puerto en Pichilemu: Histórica Bitácora del Engaño |trans_title=Port in Pichilemu: Historical Log of the Deception|author=Saldías, Washington |authorlink=Washington Saldías González |publisher=Pichilemu News |language=es |url=http://pichilemunews.blogcindario.com/2006/11/01068-puerto-en-pichilemu-historica-bitacora-del-engano.html |date=16 November 2006|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gOR |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> Homes were built along the dock on what currently is the [[Daniel Ortúzar]] Avenue (Avenida Daniel Ortúzar).<ref name="depichilemu">{{cite web|url=http://www.depichilemu.cl/historia.htm |title= Reseña Histórica de Pichilemu |trans_title=Historical overview of Pichilemu |publisher=DePichilemu |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gP2 |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Ducal">{{cite web |url= https://www.u-cursos.cl/fau/2010/1/AO501/1/material_alumnos/objeto/10442 |author1=Muñoz Hernandez |author2=Marisol D. |title=AO501-1 Taller de Diseño Arquitectonico 1 2010, Semestre Otoño |trans_title=AO501-1 Architectural Design Workshop 1 2010, Autumn Semester |publisher=Universidad de Chile |language=es |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707012955/https://www.u-cursos.cl/fau/2010/1/AO501/1/material_alumnos/bajar?id_material=10442|archivedate=7 July 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The name ''Pichilemu'' comes from the [[Mapudungún]] words ''[[wikt:pichi#Mapudungun|pichi]]'' (little) and ''[[wikt:lemu#Mapudungun|lemu]]'' (forest).<ref name="Escolares">{{cite web |url= http://www.escolares.net/descripcion.php?ide=563|title=Diccionario Mapuche |trans_title=Mapuche Dictionary |work=Escolares.net |language=es|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612035318/http://escolares.net/descripcion.php?ide=563 |archivedate=12 June 2010|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
During the [[1891 Chilean Civil War]], [[Daniel Ortúzar]] and the priest of [[Alcones]] were transferred as prisoners from Pichilemu to [[Valparaíso]] via the dock,<ref name="Guerra civil">{{cite book |author=Núñez Pinto, Jorge |year=2003 |language=es |title=1891, Crónica de la Guerra Civil |trans_title=1891, Chronicle of the Civil War |location=Santiago |publisher=[[LOM Ediciones]] |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=n71SIc6IZE8C&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38 38] |isbn=956-282-527-2 }}</ref><ref name="historia pichi">{{Cite web|title=Pichilemu y su historia|language=Spanish|publisher=Pichilemu |url= http://www.pichilemu.cl/turismo/historia/index.htm }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> which was later burned.<ref name="Puerto" /> The dock was later reconstructed and used until 1912, but it never reached "port" status.<ref name="Thesis Municipality"/><ref name="Puerto" />
The inheritors of Lauriano Gaete and Ninfa Vargas, who were proprietors of the land which is currently Central Pichilemu, founded the town in late 1891 after conceiving the design of the city with engineer Emilio Nichón.<ref name="historia pichi" /> By decree of President [[Jorge Montt]] and his Interior Minister, Manuel José Irarrázabal, the city was officially established as an "autonomous [[communes of Chile|commune]]" on 22 December 1891.<ref name="historia pichi"/><ref name="Primer alcalde">{{cite web |url= http://pichilemunews.blogcindario.com/2007/08/01679-alcaldes-regidores-y-concejales-de-la-comuna-de-pichilemu.html |title=Alcaldes, regidores y concejales de la comuna de Pichilemu |trans_title=Mayors, aldermen and councilors of the commune of Pichilemu |publisher=[[Pichilemu News]] |author=Saldías, Washington |authorlink=Washington Saldías González |date=2 August 2007 |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gOk |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> [[José María Caro Martínez]] became the first [[Mayor of Pichilemu|mayor]] of the city in 1894,<ref name="Primer alcalde" /> and regularised and improved the design of the city the same year.<ref name="Ducal" /><ref name="historia pichi" /> Caro Martínez held the mayor office until 1905.<ref name="Primer alcalde" />
[[File:Agustín Ross crop.jpg|thumb|alt=A grey haired man with several small children|Agustín Ross, circa 1915]]
[[Agustín Ross Edwards]], a Chilean writer, [[Member of Parliament]], [[minister (government)|minister]], and politician,<ref name="Millas">{{cite book|author=Millas, Hernán |year=2005 |title=La Sagrada Familia |trans_title=The Sacred Family|language=es |publisher=Editorial Planeta|isbn=956-247-381-3}}</ref><ref name="Pichilemu News Ross">{{cite web|url= http://pichilemunews.blogcindario.com/2010/02/03270-don-agustin-ross-edwards-a-166-anos-del-natalicio-del-impulsor-del-balneario-de-pichilemu.html|title=Don Agustín Ross Edwards: A 166 años del natalicio del impulsor del balneario de Pichilemu|trans_title=Sir Agustín Ross Edwards: 166 years from the birth of the promoter of the Pichilemu resort|publisher=[[Pichilemu News]]|author=Saldías, Washington |date=5 February 2010|language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gOt|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Agustín Ross Edwards – Senador|trans_title=Agustín Ross Edwards – Senator|publisher=Biblioteca Nacional de Chile|language=es |url= http://biografias.bcn.cl/pags/biografias/detalle_par.php?id=712 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gUu |archivedate=26 February 2013}}</ref> bought a {{convert|300|ha|acre|adj=on}} tract of land, and named it La Posada, in 1885. At the time, it was merely a set of thick-walled barracks.<ref name="CMN" />
Agustín Ross turned Pichilemu into a summer [[resort town]] for affluent people from [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]]. He designed an urban setting that included [[Agustín Ross Park|a park]] and a forest of over {{convert|10|ha|acre}}.<ref name="CMN" /><ref name="Easter Island">{{cite book |title=Chile and Easter Island |author=Beech, Charlotte |author2=Attwooll, Jolyon |author3=Kohnstamm, Thomas |author-link3=Thomas Kohnstamm |author4=Nystrom, Andrew Dean |year=2006 |location=[[Footscray, Victoria]], Australia |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=mw0KeQWVtsEC&pg=PT138 138] |publisher=[[Lonely Planet]] |isbn=978-1-74059-997-9}}</ref> He transformed La Posada into a hotel, named [[Agustín Ross Hotel|Gran Hotel Pichilemu]], which has since been renamed to Hotel Agustín Ross. He built the [[Agustín Ross Cultural Centre|Ross Casino]] (currently a cultural centre), several chalets, terraces, embankments, stone walls, a [[Agustín Ross Balcony|balcony]] facing the beach, and several large homes with building materials and furniture imported from France and England. However, Ross was not able to build the dock he had planned for the city.<ref name="Consejo">{{cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.cl/OpenSupport_Monumento/asp/PopUpFicha/ficha_publica.asp?monumento=1173 |title=Casino (antiguo) de Pichilemu y los Jardínes del Parque Agustin Ross |trans_title=(Old) Casino of Pichilemu and the Gardens of the Agustín Ross Park |publisher=[[National Monuments Council]] |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gPT|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> He died in 1926 in [[Viña del Mar]]. Agustín Ross' inheritors donated all of his construction (streets, avenues, squares, seven hectares of forests, the park in front of the hotel, the [[perron (staircase)|perron]]s, the balcony, and the terraces) to the [[Pichilemu city hall|Municipality of Pichilemu]], on the condition that the municipality would hold them for recreation and public access.<ref name="CMN" /> The Agustín Ross Casino, constructed in 1905, and the [[Agustín Ross Park]], constructed in 1885, have since become an important part of the city, and have been declared ''[[National Monuments of Chile|Monumentos Históricos]]'' (Historic Monuments) by the [[National Monuments Council]].<ref name="CMN" />
After the creation of the [[Cardenal Caro Province]], by decree of General [[Augusto Pinochet]] on 3 October 1979, Pichilemu became its capital.<ref name="Saldías">{{cite news|url=http://pichilemunews.blogcindario.com/2005/10/00370-provincia-cardenal-caro-de-cumpleanos.html|title=Provincia Cardenal Caro de cumpleaños|last=Saldías|first=Washington|date=3 October 2005|publisher=[[Pichilemu News]]|language=es |location=Pichilemu, [[Chile]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gPB |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> The province is named after the first Chilean Catholic Cardinal, [[José María Caro Rodríguez]], who was born in Pichilemu.<ref name="En nuestra tierra huasa"/><ref>{{Cite web |url= http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/chile/cl_appen.html |title=Chile |publisher=[[Library of Congress]] |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gPK |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vi.cl/secciones/turismo/cardenal_caro.html|title=Cardenal Caro|publisher=VI.cl |language=es|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gW5|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Pichilemu was severely affected by the [[2010 Chile earthquake]] and its subsequent tsunami, which caused massive destruction in the coastal zone.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.radiobiobio.cl/2010/03/02/pichilemu-queda-devastado-tras-el-tsunami-que-afecto-a-la-zona-costera/ |title=Pichilemu queda devastado tras el tsunami que afectó a la zona costera |trans_title=Pichilemu devastated after tsunami that affected coastal area |publisher=Radio Bío Bío |language=es |date=2 March 2010 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gQC |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> On 11 March 2010, at 11:39:41 (14:39:41 UTC), a [[moment magnitude scale|magnitude]] [[2010 Pichilemu earthquake|6.9 earthquake]] occurred {{convert|15|km|mi|0}} northwest of Pichilemu,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://sismologia.cl/events/sensibles/2010/03/20100311143929.html |title=Informe de Sismo. |trans_title=Earthquake Report. |publisher=University of Chile |date=11 March 2010 |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6EhoGmKAj|archivedate=15 July 2012|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/recenteqsww/Quakes/us2010tsa6.php |title=Magnitude 6.9 – LIBERTADOR O'HIGGINS, CHILE |publisher=[[USGS]] |date=11 March 2010 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gTC|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> killing one person.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.latercera.com/contenido/680_233172_9.shtml |title=Hombre fallece en Talca de un paro cardíaco en medio de fuertes réplicas |trans_title=Man dies in Talca of a heart attack amidst strong aftershocks |publisher=[[La Tercera]] |date=11 March 2010 |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gSv|deadurl=no |archivedate=26 February 2013}}</ref>
{{wide image|Main beach-pichilemu-2010eq edit.jpg|800px|A panoramic view of Pichilemu beach shortly after the [[2010 Chile earthquake]].}}
== Geography == [[File:Aerial view of Pichilemu, Chile.jpg|thumb|left|Aerial view of Pichilemu. The urban area is located at the top, while [[Punta de Lobos]] can be seen at the bottom.]]
Pichilemu is located {{convert|126|km|link=on}} west of [[San Fernando, Chile|San Fernando]], in the westernmost area of the [[O'Higgins Region]], on the coast of the Pacific Ocean.<ref name="Britannica">{{cite web|publisher=[[Encyclopaedia Britannica]] |year=2008 |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/459359/Pichilemu |title=Pichilemu|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gQV |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no }}</ref> It is within a three-hour drive of the [[Andes Mountains]].<ref name="Maps San Fernando">{{cite web |url=http://maps.google.cl/maps?f=d&source=s_d&hl=es&geocode=&saddr=pichilemu&daddr=san+fernando&sll=-34.584006,-70.987426&sspn=0.065435,0.154324&g=san+fernando&ie=UTF8&z=10 |publisher=[[Google Maps]] Chile |accessdate=December 16, 2009 |title=Pichilemu to San Fernando|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6EjdsEQZ6}}</ref> It is near the Cordillera de la Costa (Coastal Mountain Range) which rises to {{convert|2000|m|ft|0}} in elevation.<ref name="BCN Relieve">{{cite web |url= http://siit2.bcn.cl/nuestropais/region6/relieve.htm |title=Relieve Región Libertador B. O'Higgins |trans_title=Geomorphology of Libertador B. O'Higgins Region |publisher=Biblioteca del Congreso Nacional de Chile |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gUB|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no }}</ref>
The city is bordered by [[Litueche]] to the north, [[Paredones]] to the south, and [[Marchigüe]] and [[Pumanque]] to the east. To the west lies the Pacific Ocean.<ref name="Pichilemu antes">{{cite web |title=Pichilemu antes |trans_title=Pichilemu before |author=Pichilemu.cl |language=es |url=http://pichilemu.cl/turismo/historia/animacion/Pichilemu+antes.exe }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Pichilemu covers an area of {{convert|749.1|km2|link=on}}.<ref name="INE" />
Pichilemu is located close to a [[Pichilemu Fault|geological fault]] (Pichilemu Fault), which is according to reports between the city and [[Vichuquén]] at 15 km depth, 40 km in length and 20 km wide.<ref name="Fernández">{{cite news|url=http://latercera.com/contenido/680_261687_9.shtml|title=Pichilemu tiene falla geológica que genera oleada de réplicas en esa zona|trans_title=Pichilemu has geological fault that generates wave of aftershocks in that area|last=Fernández|first=O.|date=22 May 2010 |publisher=[[La Tercera]]|language=es |location=[[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]], [[Chile]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gTL|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> It is not known whether the fault was formed during the [[2010 Pichilemu earthquake|March 2010 earthquake]] or if it was just reactivated.<ref name="Correa">{{cite news|url=http://radio.uchile.cl/noticias/72407/|title=Sismólogos advierten sobre la activación de fallas después del terremoto|trans_title=Seismologists warn about activation of faults after the earthquake|last=Correa|first=Paula|work=Radio Universidad de Chile|publisher=[[University of Chile|Universidad de Chile]]|language=es |location=[[Santiago]], [[Chile]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gSc|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Although the majority of the forest areas around Pichilemu are covered with [[pine]] and [[eucalyptus]] plantations, a native forest (now the Municipal Forest) remains. It contains species such as [[Lithraea caustica|Litres]], [[Quillay]]es, [[Boldo]]s, [[Crataegus monogyna|Espinos]], and [[Cryptocarya alba|Peumos]].<ref name="Ducal" />
The city consists of an urban centre and twenty-two rural villages: [[Alto Colorado]],<ref>{{Cite DGRC|wstitle=Alto Colorado}}</ref> [[Alto Ramírez]], [[Barrancas, Pichilemu|Barrancas]], [[Cáhuil]], [[Cardonal de Panilonco]], [[Ciruelos]], [[Cóguil]], [[El Maqui]], [[El Guindo]],<ref name="ine2007" /> [[Espinillo, Chile|Espinillo]], [[Estación Larraín Alcalde]], [[La Aguada, Pichilemu|La Aguada]], [[La Palmilla]], [[La Villa, Pichilemu|La Villa]], [[La Plaza, Pichilemu|La Plaza]], [[Las Comillas]], [[Pueblo de Viudas]], [[Quebrada del Nuevo Reino]], [[Pañul]], [[Rodeillo]], [[San Antonio de Petrel]],<ref name="ine2007" /> and [[Tanumé]].<ref name="Thesis Municipality">{{cite web|author=Carla Ramírez Lechuga |url=http://www.tesis.uchile.cl/tesis/uchile/2004/ramirez_c2/sources/ramirez_c2.pdf |title=Edificio Consistorial I. Municipalidad de Pichilemu |trans_title=Town Hall Illustrious Municipality of Pichilemu|publisher=[[University of Chile]] |year=2007 |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gTn|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Nearby bodies of water (apart from the Pacific Ocean) include the [[Nilahue Estuary]], which flows to [[Cáhuil Lagoon]], [[Petrel Estuary]], which flows to [[Petrel Lagoon]], and El Barro, El Bajel, and El Ancho lagoons, the latter of which provides the city with drinking water.<ref name="Thesis Municipality" />
Pichilemu experiences a [[Mediterranean climate]], with winter rains which reach {{convert|700|mm|link=on}}.<ref name="Thesis Municipality"/><ref name="Clima">{{cite web|url=http://www.mapasdechile.com/clima_region06/index.htm |title=Clima de Chile Región Libertador Gral. Bernardo O'Higgins |trans_title=Weather of Chile: Libertador Gral. Bernardo O'Higgins Region |publisher=Castor y Polux Ltda. |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gQe |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> The rest of the year is dry, often windy, and sometimes with coastal fog. Occasionally the city receives winds as high as {{convert|150|km/h|mi/h|0}}.<ref name="colchagua-ca">{{cite web|url=http://melisa-recorridoporlasextaregion.blogspot.com/2008/01/el-que-fuera-el-ms-glamoroso-de-los.html |title=Balnearios con Historia (III) |trans_title=Beach resorts with history (III) |language=es |author=Revista Sábado, [[El Mercurio]] |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gST |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>

|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929003505/http://www.pro-ohiggins.cl/libro/cuerpo/3_1_4.html|archivedate=29 September 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref> |1895 |11829<!-- At this time, Pichilemu comprised at least two more villages which were later incorporated to the commune of Marchigüe --> |1907 |7787 |1920 |7424 |1930 |6929 |1940 |6570 |1952 |7150 |1960 |5724 |1970 |5459 |1982 |8844 |1992 |10510 |2002 |12392 |2012 |12251 }} By the 17th century, Pichilemu had 1,468 inhabitants.<ref name="Censo 1787">{{cite web|url=http://pichilemunews.blogcindario.com/2009/11/03185-censo-de-1787-la-superintendencia-y-el-diputado-de-cahuil-jose-gonzalez.html|title=Censo de 1787: La Superintendencia y el Diputado de Cáhuil, José González|trans_title=1787 Census: The Superintendence and the Deputy of Cáhuil, José González|language=Spanish|author=Saldías, Washington |author-link=Washington Saldías González |publisher=PichilemuNews|date=11 November 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gSl |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> In 1787, Pichilemu held 1,688 inhabitants,<ref name="Censo 1787" /> and the population rose to 11,829 by 1895.<ref name="censo1895" /><ref>Note: As pointed out above, this number includes several villages which now are not part of Pichilemu</ref> From there onward, the city's population progressively decreased: 7,787 inhabitants in 1907; 7,424 in 1920; 6,929 in 1930; and 6,570 in 1940.<ref name="Demography" /> In 1952, the city's population increased to 7,150 inhabitants; however, the 1960 census showed it decreased to 5,724 inhabitants,<ref name="1960censo"/> and to 5,459 in 1970.<ref name="censo1970" /> The number of people in Pichilemu reached 8,844 in 1982,<ref name="compendio" /> and in 1992, 10,510.<ref name="Demography" /> As of the 2002 census, the population comprised 12,392 people, and 6,228 households.<ref name="ine2007">{{cite web|url=http://www.ineohiggins.cl/archivos%5Cfiles%5Cpdf%5CDivisionPoliticoAdministrativa%5Cohiggins.pdf|title=División Político Administrativa y Censal Región del Libertador General Bernardo O'Higgins|year=2007|publisher=National Statistics Institute of Chile|language=Spanish|accessdate=14 May 2012}}</ref>
The 2002 census classified 9,459 people (76.3%) as living in an [[urban area]] and 2,933 people (23.7%) as living in a [[rural area]], with 6,440 men (52.0%) and 5,952 women (48.0%).<ref name="INE" /> According to the 2002 ''Casen'' survey, 544 inhabitants (4.4%) of the population live in extreme poverty compared to the average in the greater [[O'Higgins Region]] of 4.5%, and 1,946 inhabitants (15.7%) live in mild poverty, compared to the regional average of 16.1%.<ref name="Mi balcón">{{cite web|url=http://mibalcon.cl/vi-reg/hist156.htm |title=PICHILEMU: Historia, estadísticas, mapas |trans_title=Pichilemu: History, statistics, maps |publisher= Mi Balcón |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gd5|archivedate=26 February 2013}}</ref>
The [[National Statistics Institute (Chile)|National Statistics Institute of Chile]] has estimated that, as of 2010, 78.96% of the inhabitants in the city were living in an [[urban area]] and 21.04% were living in a [[rural area]], with 52.4% men and 47.5% women; the population density was estimated as 19.09 per square mile.<ref name="sinim" /> In the 2012 census, the population of Pichilemu was 13,916 inhabitants;<ref name="Censo-2012" /> although earlier estimates put it higher.<ref name="bcncomuna"/>
Most of the people from Pichilemu are Catholic, as of the 2002 census, 7,611 persons (83.44%), well above the national and regional average (69.96% and 79.08%, respectively); the [[Evangelicalism|evangelical]] population is considerably lower, at only 689 people (7.55%); 361 (3.96%) said they were Atheists or Agnostic individuals, while the remaining 460 (5.04%) are part of other religions. Based on information from the ''Casen'' survey, twenty-four persons living in Pichilemu declared themselves as [[Aymara people|Aymaras]] in 2006, and in 2009, 390 people said they were part of the [[Mapuche]] indigenous ethnic group; the survey revealed no one living in Pichilemu claimed to be either of the [[Atacama people|Atacameños]] or of the [[Rapa Nui people|Rapa Nui]] indigenous peoples.<ref name="bcncomuna" />
== Governance== {{Main|Government of Pichilemu}} [[File:Roberto Córdova, November 2010.jpg|thumb|left|[[Roberto Córdova]], current mayor of Pichilemu, on 19 November 2010.]]
Pichilemu, along with the communes of [[Placilla]], [[Nancagua]], [[Chépica]], [[Santa Cruz, Chile|Santa Cruz]], [[Pumanque]], [[Palmilla]], [[Peralillo]], [[Navidad, Chile|Navidad]], [[Lolol]], [[Litueche]], [[La Estrella, Chile|La Estrella]], [[Marchihue]], and [[Paredones]], is part of Electoral District No. 35 and belongs to the 9th Senatorial Constituency (O'Higgins) of the [[electoral divisions of Chile]].<ref name="Electoral division">{{cite web |url=http://www.elecciones.gov.cl/Sitio2009/p-cs9.htm |title=Circunscripción 9 |publisher= Ministerio del Interior |language=es |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091214153243/http://www.elecciones.gov.cl/Sitio2009/p-cs9.htm|archivedate=14 December 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Pichilemu is governed by the [[Mayor of Pichilemu|mayor]] (''alcalde''), who manages the executive function. The [[Pichilemu City Council|City Council]] (''concejo municipal'') manages the legislative function. The mayors and the councilors are elected popularly every four years, with possibility of re-election.<ref name="orga">{{cite web|url=http://pdba.georgetown.edu/Decen/Chile/chile.html|title=Chile: Political Organization / Organización Política|date=17 February 2005|work=Political Database of the Americas|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gUT |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no|publisher=[[Georgetown University|University of Georgetown]]|language=es}}</ref> Marcelo Cabrera Martínez was elected in 2008 as the new mayor with 42.08 percent of the vote;<ref name="Mayors 2008">{{cite web |url=http://elecciones.gob.cl/SitioHistorico/paginas/2008/alcaldes/comunas/candidatos/total/4801.htm |title=Votación Candidatos por Comuna Pichilemu Alcaldes 2008 |trans_title=Voting for Candidates of the Pichilemu commune – Mayors Election 2008|publisher=Ministerio del Interior |language=es |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730123237/http://elecciones.gob.cl/SitioHistorico/paginas/2008/alcaldes/comunas/candidatos/total/4801.htm|archivedate=30 July 2012|deadurl=yes}}</ref> he served from May<ref name="Cabrera regreso">{{cite web|url=http://www.elrancahuaso.cl/admin/render/noticia/19000|title= Marcelo Cabrera asumió como alcalde de Pichilemu|archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gVw |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no |trans_title=Marcelo Cabrera assumed as mayor of Pichilemu| author=El Rancahuaso Correspondents |date=19 May 2009 |language=es |publisher=El Rancahuaso}}</ref> to August 2009, when he was permanently banned from holding public office after being convicted for adulterating tickets.<ref name="Increíble">{{cite web |language=Spanish |title= ¡Increíble!, Pichilemu otra vez se quedó sin alcalde |trans_title= Incredible! Pichilemu has no mayor again|publisher= El Rancahuaso |author= El Rancahuaso Correspondents |date=19 August 2008 |url=http://www.elrancahuaso.cl/admin/render/noticia/20179 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gWE|archivedate=26 February 2013 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Then, the [[Pichilemu City Council|municipal council]] elected [[Roberto Córdova]] as new mayor on 9 September 2009.<ref name="Autoridades">{{cite web |url= http://pichilemu.cl/mun.php |title=Autoridades |trans_title=Authorities |publisher=Pichilemu |language=Spanish}}</ref> Between 2007 and 2009, Pichilemu had seven mayors,<ref name="Cabrera 3 años">{{cite web|title=Hasta 3 años de Cárcel arriesga el Alcalde de Pichilemu |trans_title=Up to three years in prison risks Mayor of de Pichilemu quedan en prisión preventiva|trans_title=Mayor and former aedile of Pichilemu remains in custody|publisher=El Rancahuaso|author=Cynthia Rey|language=Spanish|date=13 September 2007}}</ref> Roberto Córdova was popularly elected mayor for the first time in 2012 with 47.9 percent.<ref name="alcaldes2012">{{cite [[Andrea Aranda|Andrea Aranda Escudero]], Marta Urzúa Púa, Mario Morales Cárceles, Felipe Bustamante Olivares, and Hugo Toro Galaz. Both the mayor and the councilors took office on 6 December 2012, and their term will expire on 6 December 2016.<ref name="pichi2012alcalde">{{cite news|url=http://www.pichilemunews.cl/detalle.php?id=2332|title=Alcalde Roberto Córdova -votado como tal- asumirá hoy junto al nuevo concejo municipal de Pichilemu|author=Saldías, Washington|date=6 December 2012 |language=es |newspaper=[[Pichilemu News]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gVV |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
The Pichilemu Police, known in Spanish as Carabineros de Pichilemu, and officially Tercera Comisaría de Carabineros de Pichilemu, are commanded by Tomás Molina Meza.<ref name="Carabineros"/> The police station is located in front of the former [[Pichilemu post office building]], in [[Daniel Ortúzar]] avenue.<ref name="Carabineros">{{Cite web |url= http://portal.amarillas.com/Rancagua,VI/Amarillas/Carabineros-3-Comisaria-Pichilemu/profile/bIGBA |title=Carabineros – 3ª Comisaria Pichilemu |publisher=Amarillas |year=2010 |language=Spanish|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej6Jbyik|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
== Economy ==
Tourism is the main industry of Pichilemu, especially in the urban centre and some rural areas such as [[Cáhuil]] and [[Ciruelos]]. Forestry, mainly pine and eucalyptus, is another major industry. The area is also known for handicrafts.<ref name="Thesis Municipality"/> Although [[fishing]] is not very important to O'Higgins Region, due to unsuitable coastlines, it is common in Pichilemu, [[Bucalemu]], and [[Navidad, Chile|Navidad]].<ref name="Región de O'Higgins" />
Pichilemu has a clay deposit in the Pañul area.<ref name="Región de O'Higgins"/> According to archaeological investigations, pottery was first manufactured in the area around 300 [[Common Era|BCE]]. It is still a stalwart today — Ciruelos and El Copao are well known for the pottery created there.<ref name="Una aproximación">{{cite book |title=Una aproximación a nuestras raíces indígenas |trans_title=An approximation to our indigenous roots|author1=Carmen del Río |author2=M. Blanca Tagle |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=Editorial Platero |place=[[Santiago de Chile]] |year=1998 |language=es}}</ref>
== Landmarks == [[File:Municipal Forest of Pichilemu.jpg|thumb|The Municipal Forest was donated by the Ross family in 1935]]
The Bosque Municipal (Municipal Forest) was donated by the Ross family in 1935. The main access to the forest is in front of Ross Casino, near Paseo el Sol; or by a road near the [[Colegio Preciosa Sangre, Pichilemu|Colegio Preciosa Sangre]]. The forest has a footpath surrounded by [[palm tree|palms]], [[pine]]s, and many other varieties of trees.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.decolchagua.cl/secciones/turismo/cardenal_caro.html |title=Atractivos Turísticos Cardenal Caro |trans_title=Touristic Attractions of Cardenal Caro |publisher=De Colchagua |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gWx|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no }}</ref>
Conchal Indígena (Indigenous [[Midden]]) is an [[archaeological site]] of [[Conquest of Chile|pre-Hispanic]] times. It is located on the site of an ancient fishing village {{convert|1|km|link=on}} from [[Punta de Lobos]] and {{convert|0.3|km|link=on}} south of Los Curas Lagoon.<ref name="Atractivos" /><ref name="Cardenal VI.cl">{{cite web |url=http://www.vi.cl/secciones/turismo/cardenal_caro.html |title=Atractivos Turísticos Cardenal Caro |publisher=VI.cl |accessdate=15 December 2009 |language=es}}</ref> Laguna Los Curas (Los Curas Lagoon) is a natural area used for eco-tourist activities such as fishing located {{convert|7|km|link=on}} south of Pichilemu. Another lagoon, the Laguna del Perro (The Dog's Lagoon) is located {{convert|8.5|km|link=on}} south of Pichilemu. It is used for recreational activities.<ref name="Atractivos" /><ref name="Cardenal VI.cl" />
Laguna El Alto (El Alto Lagoon) is a small, rain-fed lagoon located at Chorrillos Beach that is often used for camping and picnics. The lagoon is an hour and a half drive from Pichilemu, traveling to the north by Chorrillos beach.<ref name="Atractivos" /> Poza del Encanto is a lagoon located {{convert|30|km|link=on}} from Pichilemu. It is home to a large variety of native fauna.<ref name="Lugares">{{cite web|url=http://www.pichilemu.net/Link/lugar.htm |title=Lugares |trans_title=Places |publisher=Pichilemu.net |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gaB |archivedate=26 February 2013 }}</ref> The Estero Nilahue (Nilahue Lagoon) is located {{convert|15|km|link=on}} from Pichilemu. It has several beaches, including El Bronce, El Maquí, and Laguna El Vado.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.elrancahuaso.cl/admin/render/noticia/17439&print=true |title=Los Imperdibles de Pichilemu |trans_title=The Unforgettables of Pichilemu |publisher=El Rancahuaso |author=El Rancahuaso Staff |date=April 2009 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8ga2|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no }}</ref>
St. Andrew Church is located in [[Ciruelos]], {{convert|13|km|link=on}} from Pichilemu. It was constructed in 1779, and its altar was built in the 1940s. It has a [[Pump organ|harmonium]], confessional boxes, and ancient images of saints. Its original image of [[St. Andrew]] was made of [[papier mache]]. The old parish was created by Archbishop [[Rafael Valentín Valdivieso]] in 1864. Cardinal [[José María Caro Rodríguez]] was baptized there. The [[feast day]] of St. Andrew is celebrated every November 30 at the church.<ref name="Atractivos" /><ref name="Cardenal VI.cl" />
The Museo del Niño Rural (the Rural Kid Museum) was created as an initiative of teacher [[Carlos Leyton]] and his students. It is a modern building that utilises traditional architecture. Three rooms contain a collection of stone tools, arrowheads, and clay tools made by the indigenous people of the region. Also on display are domestic tools from early colonists.<ref name="Museo Niño">{{cite web |url=http://www.vi.cl/museosycasaspatronales/museociruelos |title=Museo "Del niño rural" |trans_title=Museum "of the Rural Kid" |publisher=VI.cl |language=es|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gYa |archivedate=26 February 2013}}</ref>
El Copao is a hamlet located {{convert|14|km|link=on}} east of Pichilemu. Its main industry is domestic pottery production, using clay as a raw material.<ref name="Atractivos"/> Pañul is a settlement located {{convert|17|km}} from Pichilemu. Its name in [[Mapudungun]] means "medicinal herb." Pañul produces pottery made with locally obtained clay.<ref name="Pañul">{{cite web|url=http://www.depichilemu.cl/panul.htm|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gWo |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no |title=Pañul |publisher=DePichilemu |language=es}}</ref> [[Cáhuil]] is a small settlement located {{convert|13|km}}<ref name="Atractivos" /> south of Pichilemu. Its name in Mapudungun means "parrot place". Cahuil lagoon is used for fishing, swimming, and kayaking; kiteboarding lessons are offered on the lagoon. The [[Cáhuil Bridge]] is open to motor traffic, and has a view of the Cahuil zone. The bridge provides access to [[Curicó]], [[Lolol]], [[Bucalemu]], and other nearby places.<ref name="Lugares" />
Pichilemu was declared a [[National Monuments of Chile#Typical or Picturesque Zones|Typical Zone]] by the [[National Monuments Council]] of Chile, by decree No. 1097 on 22 December 2004.<ref name="CMN">{{cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.cl/OpenSupport_Monumento/asp/PopUpFicha/ficha_publica.asp?monumento=595 |title=Sector de Pichilemu |trans_title=Pichilemu area|publisher=[[National Monuments Council]] |author=Chrisitian Matzner |date=22 December 2004 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gVe |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
The city is home to five other National Monuments: Ross Park, [[Ross Casino]], ''El Árbol'' Tunnel, the wooden railway station, Estación Pichilemu, and [[Caballo de Agua]].<ref name="Monumentos News">{{cite web|url=http://pichilemunews.blogcindario.com/2008/05/02263-cinco-monumentos-nacionales-una-zona-tipica-en-pichilemu-y-el-dia-del-patrimonio-nacional.html |title=Cinco Monumentos Nacionales, Una Zona Típica en Pichilemu y el Día del Patrimonio Nacional|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gVM |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no |trans_title=Five National Monuments, a Traditional Area in Pichilemu and the Day of the National Heritage|language=Spanish |author=Saldías, Washington |publisher=[[Pichilemu News]]|date=22 May 2008 }}</ref>
=== Agustín Ross Cultural Centre === [[File:Antiguo Casino Ross 02-2013 1.JPG|thumb|left|250px|alt=A building made out of stone blocks with a black roof|Agustín Ross Cultural Centre, in 2013.]]
{{Main|Agustín Ross Cultural Centre}}
The current Cultural Centre, in front of Ross Park, is a three-floor casino constructed with imported materials in the early 1900s by [[Agustín Ross]]. It originally housed a mail and telegraph service, with a large store. The first casino in Chile was opened in this building on 20 January 1906.<ref name="Consejo" /><ref name="Pichilemu Mis fuentes">{{cite book|title=Pichilemu: Mis fuentes de información |trans_title=Pichilemu: My information sources|language=Spanish |publisher=El Promoucae |author=Antonio Saldías González |url=https://www.google.com/books?id=KfwbAAAAIAAJ |year=1990 |accessdate=12 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="Chile.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.chile.com/tpl/articulo/detalle/ver.tpl?cod_articulo=97835 |title=Pichilemu |author=Chile.com|publisher=Chile.com |language=es |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080326164903/http://www.chile.com/tpl/articulo/detalle/ver.tpl?cod_articulo=97835 |archivedate=26 March 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> It operated until 1932, when the [[Viña del Mar]] Casino was opened.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://pichilemunews.blogcindario.com/2007/01/01231-identidad-local-y-casino-ross-de-pichilemu.html |title=Identidad local y Casino Ross de Pichilemu |trans_title=Local identity and Ross Casino of Pichilemu |publisher=[[Pichilemu News]] |author=[[Washington Saldías González|Saldías, Washington]] |language=es |date=14 January 2007 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gYs|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no }}</ref>
The building was renovated and reopened in 2009 as a cultural arts center. It currently houses several gallery spaces and the public library. During its restoration, workers found many historical artifacts, including a copy of ''[[Las Últimas Noticias]]'' from February 1941 when Ross Casino served as a hotel; an American telephone battery dating from the period of 1909 to 1915; and a tile from the casino's ceiling signed by workers during the building's construction in 1914.<ref name="Casino histórico">{{cite web |url=http://www.elrancahuaso.cl/admin/render/noticia/11636 |title=Hallazgos históricos en la obra de restauración del ex casino Ross de Pichilemu |trans_title=Historical findings in the work of restoration of the former Ross Casino of Pichilemu|publisher= [[El Rancahuaso]] |author= Beatriz Valenzuela |date=29 October 2007 |language=es|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gYR |archivedate=26 February 2013}}</ref>
Ross Park, created by Agustín Ross in 1885, contains hundred-year-old native Chilean palms (''[[Phoenix canariensis]]'') and many green spaces. It was restored in December 1987, and is now a popular walking destination.<ref name="Atractivos">{{cite web|url=http://www.elrancahuaso.cl/admin/render/noticia/7987|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gZB |archivedate=26 February 2013 |title=Atractivos de nuestra región. Hoy: Pichilemu |trans_title=Attractions of our region. Today: Pichilemu|publisher=[[El Rancahuaso]] |author=María José Muñoz |date=24 February 2007 |language=es}}</ref><ref name="VI Región Playas">{{cite web |url=http://www.chile.com/tpl/articulo/detalle/ver.tpl?cod_articulo=1146 |title= VI Región Playas |trans_title=VI Region: Beaches|publisher=Chile.com |language=es |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224102627/http://chile.com/tpl/articulo/detalle/ver.tpl?cod_articulo=1146|archivedate=24 February 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The former casino was named National Monuments in 1988.<ref name="Atractivos" /><ref name="Monumento">{{cite web |url=http://www.vi.cl/secciones/turismo/monumentos.html |title=Monumentos Nacionales de la VI Región |trans_title=National Monuments of the VI Region |publisher=VI.cl |language=Spanish |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gVn |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> {{Clear}}
Ross hotel was created by Agustín Ross in 1885, and originally named Great Hotel Pichilemu (Gran Hotel Pichilemu).<ref name="colchagua-ca" /> It is one of the oldest hotels in Chile. Although it is still partially open to guests, it is in a state of disrepair.<ref name="CMN" />
=== Railway station{{anchor|Estación Pichilemu}}=== [[File:Ex Estación de Ferrocarriles de Pichilemu, Monumento Nacional, 9-12-2013 (11295123956).jpg|thumb|alt=A low wooden building with large windows|The old wooden railway station, Estación Pichilemu, in December 2013]] {{main|Estación Pichilemu}}
The old wooden railway station, Estación Pichilemu, constructed around 1925, is one of the [[National Monuments of Chile]].<ref name="Pichilemu Mis fuentes" /> In the O'Higgins Region, {{convert|357|km|link=on}} of railway lines were constructed, but only {{convert|161|km|link=on}} still exist.<ref name="Ferrocarril">{{cite web|url=http://pichilemunews.blogcindario.com/2007/12/01907-historia-del-ferrocarril-san-fernando-a-pichilemu.html|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gZ1|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no|title=Historia del ferrocarril San Fernando a Pichilemu |trans_title=History of the San Fernando to Pichilemu railway|publisher=[[Pichilemu News]] |author=Benedicto González |date=2 December 2007 |language=es}}</ref> The {{convert|119|km|link=on}} [[San Fernando, Chile|San Fernando]]–Pichilemu section was constructed between 1869 and 1926.<ref name="Pichilemu Mis fuentes" /> Passenger services operated on the line until 1986 and freight services were operational until 1995.<ref name="Ferrocarril" /> In 2006, the [[Peralillo]]–Pichilemu section was removed completely.<ref name="Ferrocarril" /><ref name="Historia ferrocarril">{{cite web|url=http://www.decolchagua.cl/modules.php?name=News%2526amp%253Bfile%253Darticle%2526amp%253Bsid%253D4349 |title=Historia del Ferrocarril San Fernando a Pichilemu |trans_title=History of the San Fernando to Pichilemu railway|publisher=De Colchagua |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gX6 |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
It remained in operation until the 1990s,{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} and became a National Monument on 16 September 1994.<ref name="Monumento" /> It has since become an arts and culture centre and tourism information office.<ref name="Atractivos" /> It exhibits decorative and practical objects from the 1920s, and features many old clothes.<ref name="Atractivos"/>
=== Beaches === [[File:Panoramic view of Pichilemu in 2008.jpg|thumb|left|Pichilemu's beaches are popular among local and international tourists.<ref>{{cite book |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=NAJHRVPSjr4C&pg=PA286 286] |title=Chile Footprint Handbook|author=Jani, Janak |publisher=Footprint Travel Guides|date= 2009}}</ref>]]
Pichilemu has several expansive dark sand beaches.<ref name="educ.ar" /> The water is cool all year-round, and many tourists choose to swim at the shore break during the summer months.<ref name="educ.ar" /> Common activities include bodyboarding, surfing, windsurfing, and kitesurfing.<ref name="compás">{{cite web |url= http://www.chile.com/secciones/ver_seccion.php?id=25596 |title=Al Compás de las Olas |trans_title=To the rhythm of the waves |publisher=Chile.com |language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gYj|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Surfin'"/>
The northernmost of the beaches is Playa Las Terrazas or Playa Principal (The Terraces Beach or Main Beach), which is in front of Ross Park. It is popular for surfing. Near the beach and at Ross Park, there are balustrades and long stairs dating from the early 1900s. There is a [[Agustín Ross Balcony|balcony]] over the rocks at the southern end of the beach.<ref name="Atractivos" /> It is the busiest during the summer months. Several surf schools, such as La Ola Perfecta, and Lobos del Pacífico, are located nearby, as is the fish market at Fishermen Creek.<ref name="Mi balcón" />
Located south of the town and around the other side of the Puntilla, Playa Infiernillo (Little Hell Beach) is rocky and has tide-pools.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://msi.nga.mil/MSISiteContent/StaticFiles/NAV_PUBS/SD/Pub125/Pub125bk.pdf |title=Sailing Directions (Enroute) – West Coast of South America |publisher=National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency |year=2010 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gXq |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> This area is used for fishing.<ref name="Mi balcón" /> South of Infiernillo is Playa Hermosa (Beautiful Beach), which is popular for walking and fishing.<ref name="Atractivos" />
Further south, {{convert|6|km|link=on}} from Pichilemu, [[Punta de Lobos]] has a beach sheltered from the southern winds. It is an increasingly popular destination for tourists and surfers.<ref name="Surfin'">{{cite web| url=http://www.pichilemu.cl/turismo/surf/Ingles/ |title=Surfin' in Pichilemu |publisher=Pichilemu |language=Spanish |accessdate=December 5, 2009}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Several surf contests are held there every year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pichilemu surfing championship|work=Turismo Libertador|year=2013|publisher=Sernatur (Chile's national tourism service) |location=Rancagua, Chile|language=es |url=http://www.turismolibertador.cl/en/what-to-do/category-detail-campeonatos+de+surf+en+pichilemu-TlRRPStE-T0RjPStE/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140511221824/http://www.turismolibertador.cl/en/what-to-do/category-detail-campeonatos+de+surf+en+pichilemu-TlRRPStE-T0RjPStE/ |archivedate=11 May 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> The size of waves varies throughout the year. Large swells in fall and winter can reach heights of up to {{convert|15|m}}. It is widely considered one of the best beaches for surfing worldwide.<ref name="educ.ar">{{cite web |url=http://educasitios.educ.ar/grupo1176/?q=node/52 |title=Pichilemu |publisher=Educasitios–educ.ar |language=es |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gbu |archivedate=26 February 2013 |deadurl=no}}</ref> In 2012, it was named one of the "50 most thrilling surf destinations".<ref>{{cite book|title=Surf Travel: The Complete Guide. The Planet's 50 Most Thrilling Surf Destinations |date=10 September 2012|last=Power|first=Chris|publisher=Orca Publications|ISBN=978-0-9523646-9-6|page=68|location=Newquay, Cornwall, UK}}</ref>
Pichilemu is regarded as the prime location for [[surfing in Chile]], particularly at Punta de Lobos.<ref name="Competencia">{{cite web|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gXg |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no|url=http://pichilemunews.blogcindario.com/2009/08/03105-tercer-campeonato-estudiantil-de-surf-2009-todo-un-exito.html |title=Tercer Campeonato Estudiantil de Surf 2009: todo un éxito |trans_title=Third Student Surf Championship 2009: a success|publisher=[[Pichilemu News]] |language=es |date=31 August 2009 |author=Saldías, Washington}}</ref><ref name="Fodors">{{cite book | title=Fodor's Chile: Including Argentine Patagonia | author=Fodor's | editor=Taplan, Alan | publisher=Random House | location=New York | year=2008 | isbn=978-1-4000-1967-0 | page=218 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x7igKTnjveAC}}</ref><ref name="La Gran Ola">{{cite web|url=http://www.chilevision.cl/home/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=169249&Itemid=81 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gce|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no|title=Surfistas esperan "la gran ola" en Pichilemu |trans_title=Surfers wait for "the great wave" in Pichilemu |publisher=[[Chilevisión]] |language=es }} (Video)</ref> Every October and December, an International Championship of Surf is held at La Puntilla Beach.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.vi.cl/ciudadesyatractivos/pichilemu |title=Pichilemu |publisher=VI.cl |language=Spanish |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gcC|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no }}</ref> [[Punta de Lobos]] hosts the Campeonato Nacional de Surf (National Surfing Championship) every summer.<ref name="Easter Island" /><ref>{{cite web |url= http://latercera.com/contenido/680_238850_9.shtml |title=Pichilemu convoca a mejores surfistas del mundo para participar en evento extremo |trans_title=Pichilemu convokes the best surfers of the world to participate in extreme event |publisher=[[La Tercera]] |author=Angela Neira |date=2 April 2010 |language=es|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gaT |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.emol.com/noticias/deportes/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=315673 |title=Mundial de Surf en Olas Gigantes entraría al agua la próxima semana |trans_title=World Surf [Championship] in Giant waves to begin next week |newspaper=[[El Mercurio]] |author=Carlos Jimeno Ocares |language=es |date=1 August 2008 |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8ge7|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
== Media == [[File:Entrevista Subsecretaria del Deporte Radio Entreolas de Pichilemu.jpg|thumb|Sports Subsecretary of Chile Nicole Sáez during an interview on ''[[Radio Entreolas]]'', in August 2015.]] There are three local newspapers: ''[[El Expreso de la Costa]]'' ("The Express of the Coast") is a monthly newspaper directed by Félix Calderón Vargas, first published on 30 June 2000;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bncatalogo.cl/F?func=direct&local_base=BNC01&doc_number=000996998 |title=El expreso de la costa|publisher=[[Biblioteca Nacional de Chile]]|accessdate=13 July 2013|language=es |location=Santiago, Chile|deadurl=no}}</ref> ''El Faro del Secano'' ("The Dryland's Lighthouse") was founded in November 2013 by local journalist Óscar Rojas Connell, and is distributed throughout the [[Cardenal Caro Province]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pichilemunews.cl/detalle.php?id=5367 |title=Cumplimos nada menos que 14 años de vida "online" como Pichilemunews, continuador del periódico "Pichilemu"|last=Saldías|first=Washington|authorlink=Washington Saldías González|date=14 January 2014|language=es|location=Pichilemu, Chile |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140511223429/http://www.pichilemunews.cl/detalle.php?id=5367|archivedate=11 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cedesus.cl/nosotros/equipo-de-trabajo/|title=Equipo de Trabajo|publisher=CEDESUS Pichilemu|location=Pichilemu, Chile|language=es |archivedate=11 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140511223519/http://www.cedesus.cl/nosotros/equipo-de-trabajo/ }}</ref> and ''La Voz de la Región'' ("The Voice of the Region"), published every two weeks, first appeared on 2 January 2014, and is directed by Patricio Flores Retamales.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bncatalogo.cl/F?func=direct&local_base=BNC01&doc_number=001063564|title=La Voz de la región|publisher=[[Biblioteca Nacional de Chile]]|accessdate=11 May 2014|location=Santiago, Chile|language=Spanish|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pichilemunews.cl/detalle.php?id=6309|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140511224936/http://www.pichilemunews.cl/detalle.php?id=6309|archivedate=11 May 2014|title=Club Aéreo de Pichilemu: más de 300 personas "se volaron" en circuíto aéreo por radio urbano y rural|first=Washington|last=Saldías|authorlink=Washington Saldías González|date=21 April 2014|location=Pichilemu, Chile|work=Pichilemu News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gobernacioncardenalcaro.gov.cl/n272_20-03-2014.html|title=Gobernadora Teresa Núñez sostiene reunión desayuno con los medios de comunicación de Pichilemu|language=Spanish|publisher=Gobernación Provincial de [[Cardenal Caro Province|Cardenal Caro]]|date=20 March 2014|location=Pichilemu, Chile |archivedate=11 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140511224926/http://www.gobernacioncardenalcaro.gov.cl/n272_20-03-2014.html}}</ref>
Radio services come from ''[[Radio Entreolas]]'', ''[[Radio Atardecer]]'', ''[[Radio Somos Pichilemu]]'' (directed by former Mayor Jorge Vargas González and his wife and current Councilor Andrea Aranda), ''[[Radio Isla]]'',<ref name="velaton">{{cite web|url=http://www.pichilemunews.cl/cartas.php|title=Agradecimientos por su velatón del 13 de agosto del 2012|author=Familia de José Rubau|publisher=[[Pichilemu News]]|year=2012|language=es |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej8MXbUB |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> and ''[[Radio Corporación (Pichilemu)|Radio Corporación]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://corporacionpichilemu.com/ |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gbL |archivedate=26 February 2013|title=Radio Corporación de Pichilemu|date=4 November 2011 |publisher=Radio Corporación de Pichilemu|language=es |location=Pichilemu, Chile}}</ref> A television channel, ''[[Canal 3 Pichilemu]]'', also broadcasts in the area.<ref name="Cornejo">{{cite news|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gcL |archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no|url=http://www.elciudadano.cl/2010/05/29/canal-3-de-pichilemu-television-comunitaria-desde-la-sexta-region/|title=Canal 3 de Pichilemu: Televisión comunitaria desde la Sexta Región|trans_title=Canal 3 of Pichilemu: Communitary television from the sixth region|last=Cornejo|first=Cristóbal|work=El Ciudadano|publisher=Mentes X Comunicaciones|language=es |location=[[Los Ríos Region]], [[Chile]]}}</ref>
== Education == [[File:Colegio de la Preciosa Sangre de Pichilemu.jpg|thumb|left|Secondary building of the Colegio de la Preciosa Sangre de Pichilemu]]
Education establishments in Pichilemu include [[Liceo Agustín Ross Edwards]] (Agustín Ross Edwards High School);<ref name="Escuelas" /> a [[secondary school]] in El Llano; the primary and secondary school named [[Charly's School]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.simce.cl/simce/index.php?id=228&iRBD=15522&iVRBD=5&iNivel=0&iAnio= |title=Ficha Establecimiento (Charly's School) |publisher= SIMCE |author=[[Ministry of Education of Chile]] |language=es |year=2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110831102310/http://www.simce.cl/simce/index.php?id=228&iRBD=15522&iVRBD=5&iNivel=0&iAnio=|archivedate=31 August 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref> and the primary school [[Escuela Digna Camilo Aguilar]] (Digna Camilo Aguilar School), both also located in El Llano;<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.simce.cl/simce/index.php?id=228&iRBD=11261&iVRBD=5&iNivel=0&iAnio= |title=Ficha Establecimiento (Digna Camilo Aguilar) |publisher=SIMCE |language=es |author=[[Ministry of Education of Chile]] |year=2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110831102336/http://www.simce.cl/simce/index.php?id=228&iRBD=11261&iVRBD=5&iNivel=0&iAnio= |archivedate=31 August 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Colegio Libertadores (Liberators School), a primary school in Infiernillo; [[Colegio de la Preciosa Sangre, Pichilemu|Colegio de la Preciosa Sangre]] (Precious Blood School), a primary and secondary school located near El Llano; Colegio Divino Maestro (Divine Master School), a primary school located near Cáhuil Avenue; Escuela Pueblo de Viudas (Pueblo de Viudas School), a primary school in [[Pueblo de Viudas]]; and Jardín Amanecer (Dawn Garden), a kindergarten school in El Llano.<ref name="Escuelas">{{cite web |url= http://www.mineduc.cl/index2.php?id_seccion=722&id_portal=7&id_contenido=4326 |title=Región del Libertador General Bernardo O'Higgins |trans_title=Libertador General Bernardo O'Higgins Region |work=[[Ministry of Education of Chile]] |language=Spanish|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ej2M8gbC|archivedate=26 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
[[Higher education]] first arrived at Pichilemu in 1970, when the Centro Medio Profesional de Pichilemu (Pichilemu Secondary-Professional Centre) was created; however, it was discontinued the next year.<ref>{{cite book|title=Boletín de las sesiones|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=Nt2xT46oF8Ggtwe57YiHCQ|volume=4|author=Congreso Nacional de Chile, Cámara de Diputados, Senado|year=1971|publisher=Imprenta Nacional|language=Spanish|page=3405}}</ref> In 2002, thirty-one years after the Centro Medio Profesional was discontinued, the [[Universidad Academia de Humanismo Cristiano]] (Academy of Christian Humanism University) began to give classes of Engineering in Public Gesture Management, and Engineering in Environment Gesture Management. The university worked at the dependencies of Liceo Agustín Ross Edwards until 2008. At least ten people obtained their professional titles, while other ten are still in the process of obtaining their titles, as of December 2011.<ref name="Carrerastecnicas">{{cite news|url=http://issuu.com/expreso.de.la.costa./docs/expreso_dic_2011/1|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6EGBmNEND|archivedate=7 February 2013|deadurl=no|title=6 carreras técnicas dictará Instituto Profesional en Pichilemu|last=Calderón|first=Félix|date=December 2011|work=[[El Expreso de la Costa]]|publisher=Impresos América|page=8|language=Spanish |location=Pichilemu, [[Chile]]}}</ref> In November 2011, [[Governor of Cardenal Caro Province|Governor]] of [[Cardenal Caro Province]] [[Julio Ibarra]] announced that an institute of higher education would be brought to the province,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://issuu.com/expreso.de.la.costa./docs/expresodelacosta|title=Gobierno del Presidente Piñera trae la Educación Superior para Cardenal Caro|last=Calderón|first=Félix|date=November 2011|work=[[El Expreso de la Costa]]|publisher=Impresos América|page=3|language=Spanish |location=Pichilemu, [[Chile]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Ejdx8WM0|archivedate=27 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> whose name, Instituto Profesional IPG (IPG Professional Institute), was disclosed one month later.<ref name="Carrerastecnicas"/> During the inauguration of the 2012 school year in Pichilemu, Education Regional Secretary Minister (Seremi) Pedro Larraín said IPEGE would work in the dependencies of Colegio de la Preciosa Sangre of Pichilemu.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elrancaguino.cl/rancaguino/noticias.php?cod=269|title=En Pichilemu: Año Escolar se inauguró con nuevo Instituto de Educación Superior|date=2 April 2012|work=[[El Rancagüino]]|publisher=Sociedad Informativa Regional|language=es |location=[[Rancagua]], [[Chile]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6EGAr54Z3|archivedate=7 February 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
